source:
The sinking of the RMS Titanic is one of the most infamous shipwrecks in history. On April 15, 1912, during her maiden voyage, the Titanic sank after colliding with an iceberg, killing 1,502 out of 2,224 passengers and crew. This sensational tragedy shocked the international community and led to better safety regulations for ships.

One of the reasons that the shipwreck led to such loss of life was that there were not enough lifeboats for the passengers and crew. Although there was some element of luck involved in surviving the sinking, some groups of people were more likely to survive than others, such as women, children, and the upper-class. Here, I will use the tools of machine learning to complete the analysis of what kinds of people were likely to survive the sinking.

Let's begin by importing the appropriate Python libraries and reading in the training and test data sets.

# Import libraries
from sklearn.ensemble import RandomForestClassifier
from sklearn.linear_model import LogisticRegression
from sklearn.svm import SVC
from sklearn.preprocessing import StandardScaler
from sklearn.grid_search import GridSearchCV
from sklearn import cross_validation
from sklearn import preprocessing
from collections import Counter
import matplotlib.pyplot as mp
import seaborn as sns
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
%matplotlib inline
mp.style.use('ggplot')

# Load the train and test datasets to create two DataFrames
train = pd.read_csv('/Users/degravek/Downloads/train.csv', header=0)
test  = pd.read_csv('/Users/degravek/Downloads/test.csv', header=0)
We can combine the training and test sets into one dataframe so that any operations we perfom on the data will be applied to both sets simultaneously. In a real-world scenario, this
df = train.append(test,ignore_index=True).reset_index(drop=True)
Now let's take a look at the headers of each data column to see what we're working with.

source: df.head()
The dataframe contains information regarding passenger name, age, sex, and class, among several other things. A description of each of the data columns is shown in the table below.

VARIABLE DESCRIPTIONS:
survival        Survival (0 = No; 1 = Yes)
pclass          Passenger Class (1 = 1st; 2 = 2nd; 3 = 3rd)
name            Name
sex             Sex
age             Age
sibsp           Number of Siblings/Spouses Aboard
parch           Number of Parents/Children Aboard
ticket          Ticket Number
fare            Passenger Fare
cabin           Cabin
embarked        Port of Embarkation (C = Cherbourg; Q = Queenstown; S = Southampton)
Let's summarize the data in another way.

source: df.info()

We see that the data contian 1,309 rows and 12 columns. We can also see that the 'Age', 'Cabin', and 'Embarked' columns contain missing values. We will go through these in turn to try and fill them in or remove them as best we can. Column 'Survived' contains missing values, but these are just the ones in the test set that we'll be trying to predict later. Before we begin, let's just take a quick look at the overall survival rates for men and women.

# Look at the data
ptab = pd.pivot_table(df,index='Sex',columns='Survived',aggfunc='size')
ptab = ptab.div(ptab.sum(axis=1), axis=0)
ptab.plot.barh(stacked=True)
mp.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1.0, 0.5))
mp.xlabel('Fraction of People')
mp.ylabel('Sex')

Females were overwhelmingly more likley to survive the sinking than were males. Approximately 75% of all females survived, while only 20% of males did. One could probably make a reasonable prediction of survival rates simply based on gender alone! However, there is still alot of additional useful information contained in the data that we can use to improve our predictions.

Next, let's take a look at the passenger class information. I remember reading at some point that survival rates were very much dependent upon which class you were in. First class passengers were likely given preferential treatment and were situated closer to the upper deck, possibly making it easier for them to quickly escape the ship. Unfortunatley, second and third class passengers were not so lucky.

# Look at the data
ptab = pd.pivot_table(df,index=['Sex','Pclass'],columns='Survived',aggfunc='size')
ptab = ptab.div(ptab.sum(axis=1), axis=0)
ptab.plot.barh(stacked=True)
mp.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1.0, 0.5))
mp.xlabel('Fraction of People')
mp.ylabel('Class')

There does indeed appear to be a correlation between passenger class and survival rate for both males and females. In all, roughly 60% of first class passengers survived, with survival rates decreasing significantly for each subsequent class.

Now let's next see if there is a relationship between port of departure and survival rate. Naively, I would hazard a guess that the relationship, if any exists, is very small. After all, why would the fate of, for example, a second class male passenger embarking from Queenstown (listed as 'Q' in the Embarked column) differ from one embarking from Southampton (listed as 'S' in the Embarked column)?

sns.countplot(df['Embarked'])
mp.xlabel('Port of Embarkation')
mp.ylabel('Number of Passengers')
There is only one missing value in the 'Embarked' column. Let's fill it in with the most common passenger class.
# Fill Embarked missing values
df['Embarked'] = df['Embarked'].fillna('S')

I'm a bit surprised that the effect is so large. Maybe there's more to this than meets the eye. It's likely that this effect is not due simply to geographic location in itself. Perhaps certain ports are located in places where passenger wealth levels were very different? For example, significantly more passengers embarking from port 'C' survived than did those embarking from port 'S'. Perhaps more wealthy individuals (i.e. first class passengers) boarded at 'C', while a larger fraction of poorer individuals (i.e. third class passengers) boarded at 'S'. In other words, the effect we're seeing may simply be a reflection of passenger class, among other things. Let's take a look!

# Look at the data
ptab = pd.pivot_table(df,index=['Embarked'],columns='Pclass',aggfunc='size')
ptab = ptab.div(ptab.sum(axis=1), axis=0)
ptab.plot.barh(stacked=True)
mp.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1.0, 0.5))
mp.xlabel('Fraction of People')
mp.ylabel('Port of Embarkation')

Our hypothesis was correct in that port of embarkation and passenger class show a correlation. Individuals embarking from Cherbourg port were largely first class passengers, while the majority of those embarking from Queenstown and Southampton were second and third class passengers. This may explain the previous figure suggesting Cherbourg passengers had better survival rates. However, passengers embarking from Queenstown had overall survival rates that were higher than Southampton even though more third class passengers boarded there, which is a bit surprising. Maybe there is another factor at play?

We also have available information regarding passenger ticket fares. Let's take a look at the distribution in fare values.

fig, axes = mp.subplots(nrows=1, ncols=2)
mp.tight_layout(pad=2)

mp.subplot(1,2,1)
sns.distplot(df['Fare'].dropna(), kde=False, color='r', hist_kws={"alpha": 0.8})
mp.xlabel('Fare [dollars]')
mp.ylabel('Number of Passengers')

mp.subplot(1,2,2)
sns.boxplot(x=df['Pclass'], y=df['Fare'], linewidth=0.5)
mp.xlabel('Passenger Class')
mp.ylabel('Fare [dollars]')

It looks like the vast majority of people paid fares that were less than about $25, but it seems reasonable to guess that first class passengers paid fares that were higher on average than those lodging in second of third class cabins. Ticket fares for third class passengers were in fact quite a bit lower. The fare column has one NaN, so let's fill it in with the median fare value of all third class pasengers. Let's fill in missing Fare value.
df['Fare'] = df['Fare'].fillna(12)

Lastly, of the 1,309 passengers, there are 263 missing age values. Let's take a look at the distribution of ages. We could make an educated guess at what they might be, but let's do something different instead. Let's use all of the information we have available to fit for them using a random forest regression.

fig, axes = mp.subplots(nrows=1, ncols=2)
mp.tight_layout(pad=2)

mp.subplot(1,2,1)
sns.distplot(df['Age'].dropna(), kde=False, color='r', hist_kws={"alpha": 0.8})
mp.xlabel('Age [years]')
mp.ylabel('Number of Passengers')

mp.subplot(1,2,2)
sns.boxplot(x=df['Pclass'], y=df['Age'], linewidth=0.5)
mp.xlabel('Passenger Class')
mp.ylabel('Age [years]')
mp.ylim([0,90])
Rather than simply filling in missing age values with the median or mean, we can do something a little better. Let's fill in the missing values by class.

ptab = pd.pivot_table(df,index=['Sex','AgeClass'],columns='Survived',aggfunc='size')
ptab = ptab.div(ptab.sum(axis=1), axis=0)
ptab.plot.barh(stacked=True)
mp.legend(loc='center left', bbox_to_anchor=(1.0, 0.5))
mp.xlabel('Fraction of People')
mp.ylabel('Ages')

The relationship betwee age and survival rate is more noticable for the women, with the highest rates occuring for the 20-40 year old range. The survival rate for men is fairly uniform for most adults of age greater than 20 years.

It's possible that we can improve the performance of our classifier if we do a little feature engineering. The Name column contains titles such as Mr., Master, Miss, etc. Perhaps we can gather some useful information by separating out these titles and making them a separate feature.
df['Title'] = df['Name'].apply(lambda x: x.split(',')[1].split('.')[0].strip())

We can also create a new feature where we look at total family size. This is the sum of the Parch (number of parents or children an individual has with them on the ship) and SibSp (the number of siblings or spouses an individual has with them) columns. It seems possible that those with larger families were less likely to survive, as it was difficult to wrangle everyone together in the chaos of the sinking. Also, to keep everything consistent, let's just make Parch and SibSp new columns with the "n" prefix in case we want to perform any operations on them later.
df['FamSize'] = df['Parch']+df['SibSp']
Get the dummy variables here, and concatenate them to main the dataframe, and drop intitial columns.

sex      = pd.get_dummies(df['Sex'], drop_first=True)
embarked = pd.get_dummies(df['Embarked'], drop_first=True)
parch    = pd.get_dummies(df['Parch'], drop_first=True)
title    = pd.get_dummies(df['Title'], drop_first=True)
ageclass = pd.get_dummies(df['AgeClass'], drop_first=True)
famsize  = pd.get_dummies(df['FamSize'], drop_first=True)

df = pd.concat([df,sex,embarked,title,ageclass,famsize],axis=1)
df = df.drop(['Sex','Embarked','Ticket','Name','Title','AgeClass','FamSize'],axis=1)
Drop 'Cabin' because it contains too many NaN values, split training and test sets, and scale them.

df = df.drop('Cabin', axis=1);

df_train = df.iloc[0:train.shape[0]]
df_test = df.iloc[train.shape[0]:]

sc = StandardScaler()

target = df_train['Survived']
feat_train = sc.fit_transform(df_train.drop(['Survived','PassengerId'],axis=1))
feat_test  = sc.fit_transform(df_test.drop(['Survived','PassengerId'],axis=1))
Well use a random forest classifier whose best parameters we'll find using GridSearch.

source: grid.best_params_

model = RandomForestClassifier(criterion='gini',n_estimators=600,max_depth=5)
model.fit(feat_train,target)
score = cross_validation.cross_val_score(model,feat_train,target,cv=5).mean()
print(score)
